Conexibacter stalactiti is described as a non-spore-forming, aerobic, and non-motile bacterium. The colonies formed by this species on agar plates are circular, convex, and yellowish-white in color.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequence comparisons has shown that Conexibacter stalactiti is most closely related to other members of the genus Conexibacter, which are known to be commonly found in various soil and cave environments.

The species is able to grow at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 40°C, with an optimal growth temperature of 28°C. It can tolerate a wide range of pH conditions, from pH 5.0 to 9.0, with an optimal pH for growth around 7.0.

Overall, the isolation and characterization of Conexibacter stalactiti contributes to our understanding of the microbial diversity and adaptations within cave ecosystems, which can provide insights into the ecology and potential biotechnological applications of this unique bacterial species.
